In the other model, glucose was also virtually ineffective on in vitro insulin secretion unless protein kinase A or C pathways were activated (26Shiota C. Larsson O. Shelton K.D. Shiota M. Efanov A.M. Hoy M. Lindner J. Kooptiwut S. Junti-Berggren L. Gromada J. Berggren P.O. Magnuson M.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 37176-37183Google Scholar, 28Doliba N.M. Qin W. Vatamaniuk M.Z. Li C. Zelent D. Najafi H. Buettger C.W. Collins H.W. Carr R.D. Magnuson M.A. Matschinsky F.M. Am. J. Physiol. 2004; 286: E834-E843Google Scholar). These observations prompted the conclusion that the amplifying pathway is defective in β-cells lacking SUR1 (28Doliba N.M. Qin W. Vatamaniuk M.Z. Li C. Zelent D. Najafi H. Buettger C.W. Collins H.W. Carr R.D. Magnuson M.A. Matschinsky F.M. Am. J. Physiol. 2004; 286: E834-E843Google Scholar). In the present study we compared islets from Sur1KO mice (25Seghers V. Nakazaki M. Demayo F. Aguilar-Bryan L. Bryan J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 9270-9277Google Scholar) and their wild-type controls, with the specific aim of assessing whether the absence of SUR1 (hence also of KATP channels) causes intrinsic defects in the amplifying pathway of glucose or amino acid-induced insulin secretion. The experiments were thus performed under classic conditions, but also under those conditions permitting dissociation of triggering and amplifying pathways in control β-cells, in particular after blockade of their KATP channels by a sulfonylurea. Because, by definition, the amplifying pathway involves changes in Ca2+ action, not in [Ca2+]i, the stability of the latter was consistently verified to obviate pitfalls of KATP channel-independent changes in the triggering signal (1Henquin J.C. Diabetes. 2000; 49: 1751-1760Google Scholar). Our results indicate that both glucose and amino acids are effective stimulators of insulin secretion in the absence of SUR1, and that their effects involve, in variable proportions, a KATP channel-independent increase in [Ca2+]i and an activation of the amplifying pathway. Animals—The generation and characteristics of Sur1KO mice have been described previously (25Seghers V. Nakazaki M. Demayo F. Aguilar-Bryan L. Bryan J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 9270-9277Google Scholar). Adult animals, all females, were sent from Houston to Brussels where they were used at an age of 10–14 months, i.e. older than the males used in previous studies with this model (25Seghers V. Nakazaki M. Demayo F. Aguilar-Bryan L. Bryan J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 9270-9277Google Scholar, 27Nakazaki M. Crane A. Hu M. Seghers V. Ullrich S. Aguilar-Bryan L. Bryan J. Diabetes. 2002; 51: 3440-3449Google Scholar). Controls were C57Bl/6 mice obtained from Charles River Laboratories, Brussels, and housed with test mice for use at a similar age. Only females were used for measurements of insulin secretion, whereas both males and females were used for measurements of islet [Ca2+]i. The Sur1KO mice used in the present study were slightly heavier than their female controls (29.7 ± 0.52 g, n = 32 versus 27.0 ± 0.55 g, n = 32, p < 0.001). There was no difference in morning blood glucose between the two groups, but the variability was greater in Sur1KO (106 ± 6 mg/dl, range 57–192) than in controls (100 ± 3 mg/dl, range 74–139). Solutions and Reagents—The control medium was a bicarbonate-buffered solution containing (mm): NaCl, 120; KCl, 4.8; CaCl2, 2.5; MgCl2, 1.2; and NaHCO3, 24. It was maintained under O2/CO2 (94:6) to a pH of 7.4, and it contained 10 mm glucose and 1 mg/ml bovine serum albumin. A similar solution was used as test medium after adjustment of the glucose concentration and addition of the studied substances. When the concentration of KCl was increased to 30 mm, that of NaCl was decreased accordingly; otherwise the substances were added without osmotic compensation. Ca2+-free solutions were prepared by substitution of CaCl2 with MgCl2 and addition of 200 μm EGTA. Diazoxide was a gift of Schering-Plough Avondale (Rathdrum, Ireland), glutamine was from Fluka (Buchs, Switzerland), and albumin (fraction V) was from Roche Applied Science, Belgium. Other reagents were from Sigma or from Merck AG (Darmstadt, Germany). Preparations—Islets from Sur1KO or control mice were aseptically isolated by collagenase digestion of the pancreas followed by hand selection (29Jonas J.C. Gilon P. Henquin J.C. Diabetes. 1998; 47: 1266-1273Google Scholar). The islets were then cultured for about 18 h in RPMI 1640 medium (Invitrogen, Belgium) containing 10 mm glucose, 10% heat-inactivated fetal calf serum, 100 IU/ml penicillin, and 100 μg/ml streptomycin. Measurements of Insulin Secretion and Islet Insulin Content—Overnight cultured islets were distributed in batches of 15–40, at room temperature, in control medium containing 1 mm glucose. The number of islets per batch depended on the substance tested in the subsequent experiment. Each batch of islets was then transferred into the chamber of a dynamic perifusion system (30Henquin J.C. Nature. 1978; 271: 271-273Google Scholar). The islets were then perifused at 37 °C with test solutions described in the figure legends. The effluent fractions were collected at 2-min intervals and saved for insulin assay, using rat insulin as a standard and ethanol to precipitate bound insulin (31Heding L.G. Diabetologia. 1972; 8: 260-266Google Scholar). At the end of the experiment, the perifusion was stopped, the chambers were opened, and the islets were recovered and counted before being transferred into Eppendorf tubes. After brief centrifugation, the transfer medium was removed and replaced by 500 μl of an acid ethanol mixture for insulin extraction (32Detimary P. Jonas J.C. Henquin J.C. J. Clin. Invest. 1995; 96: 1738-1745Google Scholar). Fractional insulin secretion rate was then calculated as the percentage of islet insulin content that was secreted per minute. By summing total insulin secreted during the experiment and the final insulin content, the insulin content of the islet at the beginning of the perifusions was obtained. It averaged 115.7 ± 2.6 ng/islet (n = 78) for controls and 99.8 ± 2.8 ng/islet (n = 66) for Sur1KO (p < 0.01). This difference is smaller than the 40% reported previously for islets from younger male mice of the same origin (27Nakazaki M. Crane A. Hu M. Seghers V. Ullrich S. Aguilar-Bryan L. Bryan J. Diabetes. 2002; 51: 3440-3449Google Scholar). Measurements of Islet [Ca2+]i—Overnight cultured islets were loaded with the Ca2+ indicator fura-PE3 (2 μm, 2 h) in control medium containing 10 mm glucose. Loaded islets were then transferred (three or four at a time) into the perifusion chamber of a spectrofluorimetric system, equipped with a camera, and with which [Ca2+]i was measured as described previously (33Gilon P. Henquin J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 20713-20720Google Scholar). Because of technical constraints, the [Ca2+]i experiments are shorter than insulin secretion experiments. Presentation of Results—All experiments have been performed with islets from four to seven different preparations. Except for a few representative recordings of [Ca2+]i in individual islets, results are presented as means ± S.E. The statistical significance of differences between Sur1KO and control islets was assessed by unpaired Student's t test. Effects of Glucose on Insulin Secretion and Islet [Ca2+]i— When the perifusion medium contained a non-stimulatory concentration of glucose (1 mm), the rate of insulin secretion by control islets was very low and stable (Fig. 1). Increasing the glucose concentration to 15 mm induced a biphasic secretion of insulin, which was completely reversible upon return to the low glucose medium. In contrast, Sur1KO islets already secreted large amounts of insulin in the presence of 1 mm glucose. This high rate of secretion, that was unaffected by 3 mm glucose (not shown), progressively declined with time, but remained higher than in control islets even after 3 h of perifusion in 1 mm glucose (Fig. 1). Stimulation of Sur1KO islets with 15 mm glucose consistently caused an early but transient decrease in insulin secretion followed by an almost 3-fold, monophasic increase above the initial rate. Although this high rate of secretion started to decrease after about 50 min (min 90 of the experiment), the stimulatory effect of glucose remained evident for at least 100 min. Lowering the glucose concentration to 1 mm only partially inhibited insulin secretion. Within 15 min, the secretion rate returned to similar values as those before the stimulation but that remained substantially higher than those in Sur1KO islets maintained in 1 mm glucose from the start (Fig. 1). Because insulin secretion by Sur1KO islets was already high in 1 mm glucose, the relative stimulation by 15 mm glucose was much smaller than in control islets, but the absolute increase over baseline was similar in the two groups: 5.9 ± 0.7% per 100 min in controls and 6.2 ± 0.8% per 100 min in Sur1KO. During long experiments, apparent islet [Ca2+]i slowly but steadily increases with time (34Sato Y. Anello M. Henquin J.C. Endocrinology. 1999; 140: 2252-2257Google Scholar). This increase in control islets continuously perifused with 1 mm glucose can be seen in Fig. 2A. When these control islets were stimulated by 15 mm glucose, a small decrease in [Ca2+]i first occurred, followed by a marked and sustained increase for a few minutes, and eventually appearance of large oscillations (33Gilon P. Henquin J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 20713-20720Google Scholar, 35Santos R.M. Rosario L.M. Nadal A. Garcia-Sancho J. Soria B. Valdeolmillos M. Pflügers Arch. 1991; 418: 417-422Google Scholar, 36Roe M.W. Mertz R.J. Lancaster M.E. Worley J.F. Dukes I.D. Am. J. Physiol. 1994; 266: E852-E862Google Scholar). These oscillations are shown in a representative experiment (Fig. 2C) but, because of their asynchrony between islets, are masked by averaging (Fig. 2A). The stimulatory effect of glucose on [Ca2+]i in control islets was rapidly and completely reversible upon return to a medium containing 1 mm glucose. In Sur1KO islets, [Ca2+]i was high already in the presence of 1mm glucose (Fig. 2A) and it was not affected by an increase in the glucose concentration to 3 mm (not shown). When the results obtained in 28 islets maintained in 1 mm glucose for about 60 min were averaged (Fig. 2B), a time-dependent increase by 1.7 nm per min was measured, which must be taken into account to evaluate the true effects of glucose. Stimulation of Sur1KO islets with 15 mm glucose initially caused a marked decrease in [Ca2+]i (Fig. 2D), that was so consistent in time not to be distorted by averaging (Fig. 2, A and B). Thereafter, [Ca2+]i increased above control values (islets maintained in 1 mm glucose) (Fig. 2B). During the period 30–40 min, average [Ca2+]i was significantly (p < 0.001) higher in Sur1KO islets stimulated by 15 mm glucose (200 ± 7nm, n = 18) than in islets maintained in 1 mm glucose (169 ± 4 nm, n = 28), although average [Ca2+]i was similar in the two groups during the prestimulatory period (15–25 min). This rebound after the initial drop was, however, transient (Fig. 2, A and B); during steady-state stimulation, average [Ca2+]i was again similar in 15 mm glucose (211 ± 7 nm) and in 1 mm glucose (204 ± 5 nm). When, at the end of the experiments, the glucose concentration was lowered from 15 to 1 mm, [Ca2+]i remained high in these Sur1KO islets (Fig. 2, A and D). The difference in average [Ca2+]i between stimulated and unstimulated Sur1KO islets usually disappeared after 15 min of glucose application, when [Ca2+]i oscillations appeared (Fig. 2D). It was not our purpose to identify the mechanisms underlying the [Ca2+]i oscillations that Sur1KO islets displayed both in 1 mm glucose (Fig. 2E) and in 15 mm glucose (Fig. 2F) nor to investigate the reasons for their variable pattern and generally higher frequency in high glucose (Fig. 2, E and F). However, it is noteworthy that an oscillatory electrical activity is present in Sur1KO islets perifused with low glucose (37Düfer M. Haspel D. Krippeit-Drews P. Aguilar-Bryan L. Bryan J. Drews G. Diabetologia. 2004; 47: 488-498Google Scholar, 38Ammala C. Dukes I.D. Gengo P. Aguilar-Bryan L. Bryan J. Seghers V.J. Nakazaki M. Diabetes. 2000; 49 (abstract): A62Google Scholar) and that these oscillations become shorter and faster in high glucose (37Düfer M. Haspel D. Krippeit-Drews P. Aguilar-Bryan L. Bryan J. Drews G. Diabetologia. 2004; 47: 488-498Google Scholar). These similarities with the [Ca2+]i oscillations that we measured strongly suggest that [Ca2+]i oscillations are controlled by the membrane potential in Sur1KO as in normal β-cells. Whatever the mechanisms of the oscillations, the most important findings in the context of the present study are that [Ca2+]i and insulin secretion in Sur1KO islets are both elevated in low glucose and that high glucose markedly increases insulin secretion without further increasing [Ca2+]i, except during the transient (∼15 min) rebound following the initial decrease. Mechanisms of Insulin Secretion by Sur1KO Islets in the Presence of 1 mm Glucose—In this series of experiments we assessed whether the high rate of insulin secretion by Sur1KO islets in 1 mm glucose can simply be ascribed to the elevation of the triggering signal [Ca2+]i. Control islets were studied in a usual medium or after blockade of KATP channels by a high concentration of tolbutamide (500 μm). Fig. 3 (A and B) shows again that, in the presence of 1 mm glucose, [Ca2+]i was higher and insulin secretion markedly increased in Sur1KO islets as compared with control islets. [Ca2+]i was even higher in control islets perifused with 1 mm glucose and 500 μm tolbutamide, but insulin secretion was surprisingly less than in Sur1KO islets. Despite the major differences in initial [Ca2+], omission of extracellular Ca2+i was followed by a decrease in [Ca2+]i to a similar level in the three groups of islets (Fig. 3A). Simultaneously, basal insulin secretion from control islets marginally, but consistently, increased, whereas the high rates of secretion in Sur1KO and control plus tolbutamide islets decreased, to reach the same rate of secretion as that of control islets (Fig. 3B). All these changes in [Ca2+]i and insulin secretion were entirely reversible upon reintroduction of CaCl2 into the medium. To evaluate the role of energy for insulin secretion by Sur1KO islets in 1 mm glucose, azide, a mitochondrial poison, was added to the perifusion medium. In both control and Sur1KO islets, azide caused an increase in [Ca2+]i (Fig. 3C), which we ascribe to arrest of Ca2+ pumping into and release of Ca2+ from intracellular stores. Basal insulin secretion from control islets was unaffected, but the high secretion rate from Sur1KO islets was progressively inhibited (Fig. 3D). Removal of azide was followed by a decrease in [Ca2+]i. In Sur1KO islets this decrease was marked and of variable duration, which gives a peculiar, progressive, stepwise pattern to the recovery after averaging (Fig. 3C). Insulin secretion recovered partially but, for unknown reasons, slightly more rapidly than [Ca2+]i. This inhibition of insulin secretion in low glucose is not specific to azide. Thus, inhibition of mitochondrial metabolism by 10 μm FCCP, 5 μm oligomycin, 10 μm rotenone, or simply lowering the temperature to 22 °C also suppressed (90% or more) insulin secretion by Sur1KO islets incubated in 1 mm glucose. These experiments establish that the high rate of insulin secretion by Sur1KO islets in low glucose results from a continuous, unregulated, influx of Ca2+, secondary to the lack of functional KATP channels, and a metabolic regulation of the effectiveness of Ca2+. Sur1KO Islets Are Insensitive to Diazoxide and Tolbutamide—In control islets, [Ca2+]i was high during stimulation by 15 mm glucose (Fig. 4A). Addition of 100 μm diazoxide, to open KATP channels, rapidly lowered [Ca2+]i, an effect that was completely and reversibly counteracted by 100 μm tolbutamide. These changes in [Ca2+]i were paralleled by changes in insulin secretion. Addition of diazoxide during sustained stimulation with glucose virtually abrogated insulin secretion, which was reversibly restored by addition of tolbutamide on top of diazoxide (Fig. 4B). The behavior of Sur1KO islets was strikingly different. Their [Ca2+]i in the presence of 15 mm glucose alone was similar to that in control islets (Fig. 4A), but the insulin secretion rate was again higher (Fig. 4B). Neither diazoxide alone nor its subsequent combination with tolbutamide affected [Ca2+]i or insulin secretion. Note that the apparent, paradoxical, decrease in insulin secretion occurring in the presence of tolbutamide around 100 min of the experiments (Fig. 4B) coincides with the onset of a spontaneous decrease in the effect of glucose alone (Fig. 1). Insulin secretion was also measured in the presence of 1 μm forskolin, which is known to increase the cAMP content of mouse islets ∼10-fold (39Henquin J.C. Meissner H.P. Endocrinology. 1984; 115: 1125-1134Google Scholar). In control islets forskolin was without effect on basal insulin secretion, but it potentiated the response to 15 mm glucose 4- to 5-fold and did not alter the inhibitory effect of diazoxide and its reversal by tolbutamide (Fig. 4C). In Sur1KO islets, forskolin increased insulin release 4-fold already in the presence of 1 mm glucose. Importantly, the stimulation by 15 mm glucose produced qualitatively and quantitatively similar effects as those in the absence of forskolin: an initial transient decrease and a sustained 2.5-fold amplification. Addition of diazoxide and tolbutamide were again without effect. Under these conditions, the changes in [Ca2+]i were similar to those in the absence of forskolin (data not shown). In a series of four experiments similar to those shown in Fig. 4B, tolbutamide was not withdrawn at 110 min, but 1 μm forskolin was added. This resulted in a potentiation of insulin secretion by 4-fold in control islets and 3.5-fold in Sur1KO islets. These experiments thus establish that Sur1KO islets are insensitive to the normal inhibitory and stimulatory effects of diazoxide and tolbutamide and that the stimulatory effect of glucose on insulin secretion persists in the presence of elevated cAMP levels. Insulin Secretion under Conditions Testing the Amplification Pathway in Control Islets—Two experimental approaches are classically used to study the amplifying pathway of glucose-induced insulin secretion: to hold KATP channels closed by a sulfonylurea or to hold them open by diazoxide and depolarize β-cells with KCl before addition of glucose (1Henquin J.C. Diabetes. 2000; 49: 1751-1760Google Scholar). In control islets, perifused with 1 mm glucose, 500 μm tolbutamide induced a rapid and sustained increase in [Ca2+]i (Fig. 5A). Subsequent stimulation with 15 mm glucose caused a rapid, transient decrease in [Ca2+]i followed by a return slightly above initial values (34Sato Y. Anello M. Henquin J.C. Endocrinology. 1999; 140: 2252-2257Google Scholar), whereas the final switch to 1 mm glucose was accompanied by a small increase in [Ca2+]i (Fig. 5A). Under similar conditions, tolbutamide induced a rapid increase in insulin secretion followed by a lower, sustained second phase, which was markedly and reversibly increased by the subsequent rise in the glucose concentration (Fig. 5B). No initial drop in insulin secretion is visible after averaging, because the phenomenon was not consistent. In Sur1KO islets, [Ca2+]i was high in 1 mm glucose and unaffected by tolbutamide, whereas 15 mm glucose induced a transient decrease in [Ca2+]i followed by a return slightly above initial values (Fig. 5A). Simultaneously, the high rate

Some murine retroviruses cause a spongiform neurodegenerative disease exhibiting pathology resembling that observed in transmissible spongiform encephalopathies. The neurovirulence of these “spongiogenic retroviruses” is determined by the sequence of their respective envelope proteins, although the mechanisms of neurotoxicity are not understood. We have studied a highly neurovirulent virus called FrCasE that causes a rapidly progressive form of this disease. Recently, transcriptional markers of endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress were detected during the early preclinical period in the brains of FrCasE-infected mice. In contrast, ER stress was not observed in mice infected with an avirulent virus, F43, which carries a different envelope gene, suggesting a role for ER stress in disease pathogenesis. Here we have examined in NIH 3T3 cells the cause of this cellular stress response. The envelope protein of F43 bound BiP, a major ER chaperone, transiently and was processed normally through the secretory pathway. In contrast, the envelope protein of FrCasE bound to BiP for a prolonged period, was retained in the ER, and was degraded by the proteasome. Furthermore, engagement of the FrCasE envelope protein by ER quality control pathways resulted in decreased steady-state levels of this protein, relative to that of F43, both in NIH 3T3 cells and in the brains of infected mice. Thus, the ER stress induced by FrCasE appears to be initiated by inefficient folding of its viral envelope protein, suggesting that the neurodegenerative disease caused by this virus represents a protein misfolding disorder. Some murine retroviruses cause a spongiform neurodegenerative disease exhibiting pathology resembling that observed in transmissible spongiform encephalopathies. The neurovirulence of these “spongiogenic retroviruses” is determined by the sequence of their respective envelope proteins, although the mechanisms of neurotoxicity are not understood. We have studied a highly neurovirulent virus called FrCasE that causes a rapidly progressive form of this disease. Recently, transcriptional markers of endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress were detected during the early preclinical period in the brains of FrCasE-infected mice. In contrast, ER stress was not observed in mice infected with an avirulent virus, F43, which carries a different envelope gene, suggesting a role for ER stress in disease pathogenesis. Here we have examined in NIH 3T3 cells the cause of this cellular stress response. The envelope protein of F43 bound BiP, a major ER chaperone, transiently and was processed normally through the secretory pathway. In contrast, the envelope protein of FrCasE bound to BiP for a prolonged period, was retained in the ER, and was degraded by the proteasome. Furthermore, engagement of the FrCasE envelope protein by ER quality control pathways resulted in decreased steady-state levels of this protein, relative to that of F43, both in NIH 3T3 cells and in the brains of infected mice. Thus, the ER stress induced by FrCasE appears to be initiated by inefficient folding of its viral envelope protein, suggesting that the neurodegenerative disease caused by this virus represents a protein misfolding disorder. Several murine retroviruses cause vacuolar brain disease closely resembling the pathology caused by the transmissible spongiform encephalopathy (TSE) 1The abbreviations used are: TSE, transmissible spongiform encephalopathy; ER, endoplasmic reticulum; RT-PCR, reverse transcriptase; Bistris, 2-[bis(2-hydroxyethyl)amino]-2-(hydroxymethyl)propane-1,3-diol; UPR, unfolded protein response; MHC, major histocompatibility complex; ERAD, ER-associated degradation; SU, the surface glycoprotein; dpi, days post-infection; PrP, prion protein. 1The abbreviations used are: TSE, transmissible spongiform encephalopathy; ER, endoplasmic reticulum; RT-PCR, reverse transcriptase; Bistris, 2-[bis(2-hydroxyethyl)amino]-2-(hydroxymethyl)propane-1,3-diol; UPR, unfolded protein response; MHC, major histocompatibility complex; ERAD, ER-associated degradation; SU, the surface glycoprotein; dpi, days post-infection; PrP, prion protein. agents. The neurovirulence of these “spongiogenic retroviruses” is determined by the sequence of their respective envelope genes (1DesGroseillers L. Barrette M. Jolicoeur P. J. Virol. 1984; 52: 356-363Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 2Masuda M. Remington M.P. Hoffman P.M. Ruscetti S.K. J. Virol. 1992; 66: 2798-2806Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 3Szurek P.F. Yuen P.H. Ball J.K. Wong P.K.Y. J. Virol. 1990; 64: 467-475Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), although the molecular interactions of the viral envelope protein and the host that lead to neurodegeneration remain to be elucidated. Previous studies by others (3Szurek P.F. Yuen P.H. Ball J.K. Wong P.K.Y. J. Virol. 1990; 64: 467-475Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 4Shikova E. Lin Y.C. Saha K. Brooks B.R. Wong P.K.Y. J. Virol. 1993; 67: 1137-1147Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) have suggested that endoplasmic reticulum (ER) retention of the envelope protein may play a role in the pathogenic process. Supporting this hypothesis, we demonstrated that a transcriptional profile consistent with an ER stress response is activated in the brains of mice infected with a neuropathogenic virus FrCasE but not in mice infected with a nonpathogenic retrovirus F43 (5Dimcheff D.E. Askovic S. Baker A.H. Johnson-Fowler C. Portis J.L. J. Virol. 2003; 77: 12617-12629Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). The FrCasE and F43 viruses were constructed by using the same retrovirus genetic background but differ in their envelope genes (6Askovic S. McAtee F.J. Favara C. Portis J.L. J. Virol. 2000; 74: 465-473Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar). FrCasE contains the envelope gene of CasBrE, a neuropathogenic retrovirus originally isolated from wild mice (7Gardner M.B. Henderson B.E. Officer J.E. Rongey R.W. Parker J.C. Oliver C. Estes J.D. Huebner R.J. J. Natl. Cancer Inst. 1973; 51: 1243-1254Crossref PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar), whereas F43 contains the envelope gene of a nonpathogenic virus FMLV 57. Both viruses utilize the same receptor for virus entry, infect the brain at high levels, and target the same cell populations (6Askovic S. McAtee F.J. Favara C. Portis J.L. J. Virol. 2000; 74: 465-473Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar). Most interesting, NIH 3T3 cells infected with FrCasE also exhibit a transcriptional profile consistent with ER stress (5Dimcheff D.E. Askovic S. Baker A.H. Johnson-Fowler C. Portis J.L. J. Virol. 2003; 77: 12617-12629Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar), suggesting that these cells could be used to further analyze the interactions between the virus and the host cell that initiates this response. ER stress is caused by conditions that perturb ER function including nutrient or energy deprivation, calcium fluxes, and the accumulation of misfolded proteins (8Kaufman R.J. Genes Dev. 1999; 13: 1211-1233Crossref PubMed Scopus (1923) Google Scholar, 9Kaufman R.J. Scheuner D. Schroder M. Shen X. Lee K. Liu C.Y. Arnold S.M. Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2002; 3: 411-421Crossref PubMed Scopus (496) Google Scholar). When misfolded proteins accumulate in the ER, a stereotypical cellular program to eliminate this stress, called the unfolded protein response (UPR), is activated (8Kaufman R.J. Genes Dev. 1999; 13: 1211-1233Crossref PubMed Scopus (1923) Google Scholar). Central to the UPR is the binding of BiP (grp78), an ATP-dependent ER chaperone, to misfolded proteins (10Bertolotti A. Zhang Y. Hendershot L.M. Harding H.P. Ron D. Nat. Cell Biol. 2000; 2: 326-332Crossref PubMed Scopus (2080) Google Scholar, 11Kaufman R.J. J. Clin. Investig. 2002; 110: 1389-1398Crossref PubMed Scopus (1079) Google Scholar, 12Shen J. Chen X. Hendershot L. Prywes R. Dev. Cell. 2002; 3: 99-111Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1052) Google Scholar). BiP binds transiently to newly synthesized proteins but more persistently to misfolded proteins. Under nonstressed conditions, BiP binds to three ER resident transmembrane proteins called “sensors of ER stress,” which negatively regulates the UPR by keeping these proteins in an inactivated state. When misfolded proteins accumulate in the ER, BiP binds instead to the misfolded proteins and allows activation of these UPR sensors, leading to decreased protein synthesis and increased production of ER chaperones (13Rutkowski D.T. Kaufman R.J. Trends Cell Biol. 2004; 14: 20-28Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1178) Google Scholar). This is followed by activation of ER-associated degradation (ERAD), which shunts misfolded proteins to the proteasome (14Brodsky J.L. McCracken A.A. Semin. Cell Dev. Biol. 1999; 10: 507-513Crossref PubMed Scopus (298) Google Scholar). In this way BiP monitors the folding status of proteins in the ER and regulates the UPR in response to ER stress. Several human neurodegenerative diseases are associated with the accumulation of misfolded host proteins, although the specific role played by misfolded proteins in disease pathogenesis remains elusive. ER stress pathways and the subsequent cellular responses may provide a mechanistic connection between misfolded proteins and disease (11Kaufman R.J. J. Clin. Investig. 2002; 110: 1389-1398Crossref PubMed Scopus (1079) Google Scholar). For instance, ER stress can lead to oxidative stress (15Harding H.P. Zhang Y. Zeng H. Novoa I. Lu P.D. Calfon M. Sadri N. Yun C. Popko B. Paules R. Stojdl D.F. Bell J.C. Hettmann T. Leiden J.M. Ron D. Mol. Cell. 2003; 11: 619-633Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2335) Google Scholar, 16Tu B.P. Weissman J.S. J. Cell Biol. 2004; 164: 341-346Crossref PubMed Scopus (806) Google Scholar) as well as the initiation of cell death pathways (17Breckenridge D.G. Germain M. Mathai J.P. Nguyen M. Shore G.C. Oncogene. 2003; 22: 8608-8618Crossref PubMed Scopus (649) Google Scholar). The effects of ER stress may participate in the pathogenesis of a number of degenerative diseases such as Parkinson's (18Imai Y. Soda M. Hatakeyama S. Akagi T. Hashikawa T. Nakayama K.I. Takahashi R. Mol. Cell. 2002; 10: 55-67Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (422) Google Scholar), Huntington's (19Nishitoh H. Matsuzawa A. Tobiume K. Saegusa K. Takeda K. Inoue K. Hori S. Kakizuka A. Ichijo H. Genes Dev. 2002; 16: 1345-1355Crossref PubMed Scopus (1131) Google Scholar), Alzheimer's (20Terro F. Czech C. Esclaire F. Elyaman W. Yardin C. Baclet M.C. Touchet N. Tremp G. Pradier L. Hugon J. J. Neurosci. Res. 2002; 69: 530-539Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar), and amotrophic lateral sclerosis (21Tobisawa S. Hozumi Y. Arawaka S. Koyama S. Wada M. Nagai M. Aoki M. Itoyama Y. Goto K. Kato T. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2003; 303: 496-503Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar), although the evidence is still circumstantial. Given the importance of misfolded proteins in neurodegenerative diseases, and the possible link between ER stress and retrovirus-induced spongiform neurodegeneration (5Dimcheff D.E. Askovic S. Baker A.H. Johnson-Fowler C. Portis J.L. J. Virol. 2003; 77: 12617-12629Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar), we investigated the virus-host interactions in NIH 3T3 cells that initiate this response. FrCasE not only up-regulated BiP RNA and protein expression in NIH 3T3 cells, but its envelope protein bound a greater amount of BiP for a longer time than the F43 envelope protein. The FrCasE envelope protein was found to be retained in the ER and degraded by the proteasome, whereas that of F43 was processed normally through the secretory pathway. Furthermore, the shunting of viral envelope protein to the degradative pathway resulted in its decreased levels both in NIH 3T3 cells and in the brains of FrCasE-infected mice. These results strongly suggest that binding of misfolded envelope protein to BiP is responsible for the transcriptional activation of the UPR in FrCasE-infected cells. Because signs of ER stress are an early event seen during the preclinical period of the FrCasE-induced neurodegenerative disease, the results presented here support the notion that this represents a virus-induced protein misfolding disease. Cell Culture and Virus Infections—NIH 3T3 cells (ATCC CRL 1658) were grown in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% calf serum at 37 °Cina5%CO2 humidified incubator. Virus stocks were prepared in Mus dunni cells as described before (22Portis J.L. Czub S. Garon C.F. McAtee F.J. J. Virol. 1990; 64: 1648-1656Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), and titers of infectivity of each virus stock were determined on NIH 3T3 cells. Cells were infected, as described previously (22Portis J.L. Czub S. Garon C.F. McAtee F.J. J. Virol. 1990; 64: 1648-1656Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), in the presence of 8 μg/ml Polybrene at a multiplicity of infection of 2–5. This multiplicity of infection was found empirically to result in the expression of viral envelope protein at the cell surface of >95% of the cells in the culture within 24 h of infection. We found no further increase in viral DNA between 24 and 48 h post-infection suggesting that there was no detectable virus spread after the initial infection. The three viruses used in this study were FrCasE (22Portis J.L. Czub S. Garon C.F. McAtee F.J. J. Virol. 1990; 64: 1648-1656Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), F43 (6Askovic S. McAtee F.J. Favara C. Portis J.L. J. Virol. 2000; 74: 465-473Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar), and a new construct FrCasNC, described herein. The FrCasNC construct was generated as described previously (6Askovic S. McAtee F.J. Favara C. Portis J.L. J. Virol. 2000; 74: 465-473Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar) for the F43 virus, except that NdeI to ClaI sites were used to insert the CasBrE envelope gene into the F43 retrovirus background (Fig. 2). Real Time Quantitative Reverse Transcriptase-PCR—Total RNA samples were analyzed using Taqman real time RT-PCR (Applied Biosystems) as described previously (5Dimcheff D.E. Askovic S. Baker A.H. Johnson-Fowler C. Portis J.L. J. Virol. 2003; 77: 12617-12629Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). The RT-PCRs were performed in triplicate on individual RNA samples, and individual independent infections were repeated in triplicate. Expression values were normalized using glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. Primer and probe sequences used to amplify BiP, GADD153/CHOP, and virus RNA were reported previously (5Dimcheff D.E. Askovic S. Baker A.H. Johnson-Fowler C. Portis J.L. J. Virol. 2003; 77: 12617-12629Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). Statistical tests were performed on multiple independent infections using analysis of variance with a Tukey's multiple-comparison post-test and a level of significance of <0.05. Mice, Inoculations and Immunohistochemistry—Inbred Rocky Mountain White mice were bred and raised at the Rocky Mountain Laboratories and were handled according to the policies of the Rocky Mountain Laboratories Animal Care and Use Committee. Mice were inoculated with virus stocks prepared in M. dunni cells, as described previously (22Portis J.L. Czub S. Garon C.F. McAtee F.J. J. Virol. 1990; 64: 1648-1656Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), or for mock infections with tissue culture medium alone. Mice were inoculated intraperitoneally 24–48 h after birth with 30 μl of virus stocks containing 1.5–3.0 × 105 focus forming units of infectivity. Immunohistochemistry using goat antiserum to viral surface glycoprotein (SU) was performed as described previously (6Askovic S. McAtee F.J. Favara C. Portis J.L. J. Virol. 2000; 74: 465-473Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar). Immunoprecipitation and Immunoblot Experiments—NIH 3T3 cells were infected, and 48 h later monolayers were washed 2× with Dulbecco's phosphate-buffered saline and lysed on ice for 10 min using the following lysis buffer: 0.5% Nonidet P-40, 0.5% deoxycholic acid, 50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 150 mm NaCl, protease inhibitor mixture (Sigma), and apyrase (10 units/ml). BiP interaction with target proteins is ATP-regulated, so we lysed cells in the presence of apyrase, an ATP diphosphohydrolase, to stabilize BiP-envelope interactions following cell lysis. Lysates were centrifuged for 2 min at 6,000 × g to pellet nuclei. Protein quantity was determined using the BCA protein assay kit (Pierce), and samples were normalized prior to immunoprecipitation. The antibodies, polyclonal rabbit anti-SU (G. Hunsmann, Goettingen, Germany), or mouse monoclonal anti-KDEL (BiP/Grp78 and Grp94) (StressGen) were added to lysates and incubated overnight at 4 °C. Immune complexes were precipitated with protein A-Sepharose beads (Pierce) and washed 3× with lysis buffer. Proteins were released from protein A-Sepharose beads by boiling 5 min in 2× sample buffer containing 2-mercaptoethanol and resolved on 10% NuPage® NOVEX Bis-tris gels (Invitrogen). To detect coprecipitated proteins, immunoblot analysis was performed using rabbit anti-SU at a 1:1000 dilution or mouse anti-KDEL at a 1:2000 dilution. A mouse anti-β-actin antibody (Sigma) was used at a 1:5000 dilution to verify BCA protein quantification and demonstrate equal loading of cell extracts. Immunoblots on 10% homogenates of brain stem were performed as described above, except brain stem samples were homogenized in Dounce homogenizers using a lysis buffer containing 1.0% Nonidet P-40, 0.5% deoxycholic acid, 50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 150 mm NaCl, 1 mm EDTA, pH 8.0, and a protease inhibitor mixture (Sigma). Rabbit anti-SU was used at a 1:1000 dilution and rabbit anti-p30 (capsid protein) (23Czub S. Lynch W.P. Czub M. Portis J.L. Lab. Investig. 1994; 70: 711-723PubMed Google Scholar) at a 1:1000 dilution. Primary antibodies were detected with species-specific horseradish peroxidase-conjugated antibodies (Bio-Rad) and visualized using the ECL system (Amersham Biosciences) on autoradiography film (LabScientific Inc.). Metabolic Labeling and Pulse-Chase Experiments—For pulse-labeling experiments, after 48-h infections, cells were washed in warm phosphate-buffered balanced salt, incubated for 30 min in methionine/cysteine-free medium, and then metabolically labeled with 200 μCi/ml [35S]methionine/cysteine for 15 min. Cells were then lysed with buffer containing 50 mm Tris, pH 7.5, 150 mm NaCl, 0.5% Nonidet P-40, 0.5% deoxycholic acid, and a protease inhibitor mixture and centrifuged at 6,000 × g for 2 min at 4 °C. The supernatant was used in immunoprecipitations. For experiments investigating BiP binding, 10 units/ml apyrase (Sigma) was added to lysis buffer. For pulse-chase analysis, after the 15-min pulse, the labeling medium was removed, and cells were washed and chased with complete medium supplemented with 2 mm methionine/cysteine at 37 °C for various times and then lysed as above. For proteasome inhibitor experiments, cells were incubated in 50 μm MG132 for 2 h prior to methionine/cysteine wash out. During the pulse and chase periods, 50 μm MG132 was included in media. Immunoprecipitations were performed as above except prior to immunoprecipitation cell lysates were normalized to total trichloroacetic acidprecipitable counts. Immunocomplexes were solubilized by boiling for 5 min in 2× SDS sample buffer containing 2-mercaptoethanol. Samples were resolved on 9% SDS-PAGE gels and, after drying, exposed to a phosphor screen (Amersham Biosciences). Bands were quantified using ImageQuant (Amersham Biosciences). For BiP-binding pulse-chase experiments, the amount of envelope coimmunoprecipitated was normalized to the amount of BiP at each time point prior to determining the half-lives. Data were fit to a nonlinear regression for one-phase exponential decay, and half-lives (t½) were calculated from the equation for the best fit curves. Immunofluorescence Microscopy—Cells were grown and infected on 12-mm glass coverslips, fixed in 3.7% formaldehyde, and permeabilized with 0.5% Triton X-100, all at room temperature. Cells were stained for 30 min at room temperature with both primary and secondary antibodies. Viral envelope protein was detected with the same rabbit anti-SU protein used for viral protein studies, and calnexin was detected with goat anti-calnexin (Santa Cruz Biotechnology). The primary rabbit antibody was developed with AlexaFluor 488 chicken anti-rabbit Ig (Molecular Probes), and the primary goat antibody was detected with AlexaFluor 555 donkey anti-goat Ig (Molecular Probes). Both secondary antibodies were highly cross-absorbed to remove interspecies cross-reactive antibodies. Initial studies using conventional fluorescence microscopy (Nikon Microphot SA) were carried out to show that the secondary antibodies were specific for their respective Ig. For colocalization studies, coverslips were also stained with the DNA dye DRAQ-5 to stain nuclei and were examined by using a PerkinElmer Life Sciences UltraView LCI confocal microscope, and 0.2–0.4-μm optical slices were acquired as a Z-series using PerkinElmer Life Sciences Imaging Suite version 5.4. Selected slices were then overlaid using Image-J software version 1.29x (Wayne Rasband, National Institutes of Health, www.rsb.info.nih.gov/ij). Flow Cytometric Analysis—Suspensions of live cells were analyzed for cell-surface expression using a FACStar flow cytometer (BD Biosciences) as described previously (24Fujisawa R. McAtee F.J. Wehrly K. Portis J.L. J. Virol. 1998; 72: 5619-5625Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). For viral envelope protein, cells were stained with polyclonal rabbit anti-SU antiserum diluted 1:1000 and detected with AlexaFluor 488 anti-rabbit IgG (Molecular Probes) diluted 1:2000. For MHC class I and transferrin receptor, cells were stained with mouse monoclonal antibodies 30.5.7S (ATCC) and TIB-219 (ATCC), respectively, and detected with AlexaFluor 488 anti-mouse Ig. For quantification of total protein, cells were fixed with 3.7% formaldehyde and permeabilized with 0.1% saponin in Dulbecco's phosphate-buffered saline prior to adding primary antibodies. Controls for specificity were performed by staining infected and uninfected cells with secondary antibody alone. Dead cells were gated out with propidium iodide, and a total of 10,000 live cells were analyzed. ER Stress Is Influenced by the Quality of CasBrE Envelope Protein—FrCasE induces the up-regulation of several markers of ER stress in the brain (5Dimcheff D.E. Askovic S. Baker A.H. Johnson-Fowler C. Portis J.L. J. Virol. 2003; 77: 12617-12629Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar), including BiP, an ER chaperone, and CHOP, a bZip transcription factor. We quantified these two transcripts in NIH 3T3 cells 48 h after infection, using real time RT-PCR. As reported previously (5Dimcheff D.E. Askovic S. Baker A.H. Johnson-Fowler C. Portis J.L. J. Virol. 2003; 77: 12617-12629Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar), both genes were up-regulated 2–3-fold by FrCasE but not F43 (Fig. 1A). However, the difference in the BiP and CHOP responses paralleled a difference in viral RNA load, which was found to be 2–3-fold higher in FrCasE compared with F43 infection (Fig. 1A). This suggested that the ER stress might simply be a consequence of ER overload. To address this issue directly, we utilized another viral construct, FrCasNC, in which 216 nucleotides in the 3′ polymerase gene of FrCasE (between SphI and NdeI) were replaced with sequences from F43 (Fig. 2A). Both viruses contain the envelope gene of CasBrE, which determines neurovirulence in this system. Indeed, the tempo of the neurologic disease induced by FrCasNC and FrCasE was indistinguishable (Fig. 2B), and both viruses induced comparable spongiform neuropathology (Fig. 2C). However, unlike FrCasE, the viral RNA load in FrCasNC-infected NIH 3T3 cells was comparable with that of F43 (Fig. 1B). Both BiP and CHOP were up-regulated by FrCasNC, and the magnitude of the effect was similar to that induced by FrCasE (Fig. 1B). Nevertheless, we monitored newly synthesized envelope protein to further establish that the ER load in FrCasNC and F43 infected cells was comparable (Fig. 1C). Forty-eight hours after infection, cells were pulsed for 15 min with [35S]methionine/cysteine, and cell lysates were immunoprecipitated with an antiserum specific for viral surface glycoprotein (SU). After a 15-min pulse, the only radiolabeled protein detected by this antiserum was the envelope precursor polyprotein pr85env. The CasBrE envelope protein encoded by FrCasE and FrCasNC is slightly smaller than that of F43 because it contains one less glycosylation site and has two deletions of 4 and 7 amino acid residues. As expected, newly synthesized pr85env was 2-fold higher in FrCasE than F43-infected cells, and consistent with the viral RNA levels, the amount of FrCasNC was comparable with that of F43 (Fig. 1C). These results suggested that an intrinsic quality of the CasBrE envelope protein, present in both FrCasE and FrCasNC, was sufficient to induce the ER stress response. The CasBrE Envelope Protein Is Retained in the ER—The envelope precursor polyprotein of these viruses (pr85env), which is synthesized in the ER, is cleaved by a cellular protease in the Golgi, generating the surface glycoprotein (SU, ∼70 kDa) and the transmembrane fusion protein (∼15 kDa) (25Swanstrom R. Wills J.W. Coffin J.M. Hughes S.H. Varmus H. Retroviruses. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1997: 263-334Google Scholar). We previously showed by immunoblot analysis that the ratio of pr85env to SU protein in cell lysates at steady-state was greater for FrCasE than F43, suggesting a delay in exit of the protein from the ER (5Dimcheff D.E. Askovic S. Baker A.H. Johnson-Fowler C. Portis J.L. J. Virol. 2003; 77: 12617-12629Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). To further examine this question, we used confocal fluorescence microscopy on fixed and permeabilized cells infected with FrCasE, FrCasNC, and F43 to compare the distribution of envelope protein (Fig. 3). The anti-SU antiserum used to stain viral envelope protein reacts with both the pr85env precursor polyprotein and the SU protein. Although the F43 envelope protein exhibited a largely vesicular staining pattern consistent with staining primarily cleaved, post-ER SU protein, the CasBrE envelope protein of FrCasE and FrCasNC had a reticular pattern that colocalized with the ER marker calnexin. These data suggest that the anti-SU antibody stained predominantly the ER-localized CasBrE pr85env precursor protein. There was very little visible colocalization of F43 envelope protein and calnexin (Fig. 3). These results support the notion that the CasBrE envelope precursor protein is retained in the ER relative to that of F43. We next examined the possible role of BiP in the ER retention of this viral protein. BiP binds to exposed hydrophobic regions and retains client protein in the ER, where it assists in protein folding (26Gething M.J. Semin. Cell Dev. Biol. 1999; 10: 465-472Crossref PubMed Scopus (434) Google Scholar). Proteins that do not fold properly remain bound to BiP for prolonged periods. We performed coimmunoprecipitation studies using anti-KDEL (reactive with BiP and grp94) and anti-SU (reactive with pr85env and SU protein). Cell lysates were split, one-half being subjected to immunoprecipitation (IP) and the other half being boiled directly in sample buffer (Total Extract). Both samples were subjected to immunoblot analysis (see Fig. 4). Immunoprecipitation with anti-KDEL coprecipitated a protein from the virus-infected cells that was reactive with anti-SU and was consistent in size with the respective pr85env proteins (Fig. 4A, compare IP to Total Extract). In addition, it was clear that the amount of pr85env coimmunoprecipitated from lysates of FrCasE and FrCasNC-infected cells was greater than that from F43-infected cells. Immunoprecipitation with anti-SU (Fig. 4B) resulted in the coprecipitation of a protein reactive with anti-KDEL that had a molecular mass of 78 kDa, consistent with that of BiP (Fig. 4B, compare IP to Total Extract). Most interesting, another KDEL-containing ER chaperone (grp 94) was not coprecipitated with pr85env. Finally, it is apparent from the anti-KDEL immunoblot of total extracts (Fig. 4B) that BiP protein was up-regulated in FrCasE and FrCasNC-infected cells, consistent with the analyses of mRNA levels (Fig. 1) (5Dimcheff D.E. Askovic S. Baker A.H. Johnson-Fowler C. Portis J.L. J. Virol. 2003; 77: 12617-12629Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). Kinetic studies of BiP binding further suggested the folding instability of the CasBrE envelope protein in the ER. Pulsechase analyses were carried out on FrCasE and F43-infected cells, using anti-KDEL antibodies to coimmunoprecipitate BiP and pr85env (Fig. 5A). The amount of pr85env coimmunoprecipitated at each time point was quantified and normalized to BiP. The ratios of pr85env to BiP at each chase time were then compared with the ratio at time 0 and converted to a percentage of pr85env remaining (Fig. 5B). From these measurements, the half-lives of the BiP-Env interaction were estimated. The binding half-life for FrCasE pr85env to BiP was 2.5 h., whereas that for F43 was 1.0 h. Results were confirmed in another independent experiment examining several time points in the 1st h after the pulse. Taken together with results from the steady-state studies, it appears that the ER retention of the CasBrE envelope protein was a function of its prolonged binding to BiP, implying that this protein folds inefficiently in the ER compared with the F43 envelope protein. FrCasE Envelope Protein Is Subjected to Proteasomal Degradation—Proteins that do not fold properly in the ER are subjected to retrograde transport to the cytosol and degradation by the ubiquitin-proteasome system. Thus, after synthesis pr85env exits the ER by vesicular transport to the Golgi for normal proteolytic processing or is

The structure of α-hemoglobin stabilizing protein (AHSP), a molecular chaperone for free α-hemoglobin, has been determined using NMR spectroscopy. The protein native state shows conformational heterogeneity attributable to the isomerization of the peptide bond preceding a conserved proline residue. The two equally populated cis and trans forms both adopt an elongated antiparallel three α-helix bundle fold but display major differences in the loop between the first two helices and at the C terminus of helix 3. Proline to alanine single point mutation of the residue Pro-30 prevents the cis/trans isomerization. The structure of the P30A mutant is similar to the structure of the trans form of AHSP in the loop 1 region. Both the wild-type AHSP and the P30A mutant bind to α-hemoglobin, and the wild-type conformational heterogeneity is quenched upon complex formation, suggesting that just one conformation is the active form. Changes in chemical shift observed upon complex formation identify a binding interface comprising the C terminus of helix 1, the loop 1, and the N terminus of helix 2, with the exposed residues Phe-47 and Tyr-51 being attractive targets for molecular recognition. The characteristics of this interface suggest that AHSP binds at the intradimer α1β1 interface in tetrameric HbA. The protein native state shows conformational heterogeneity attributable to the isomerization of the peptide bond preceding a conserved proline residue. The characteristics of this interface suggest that AHSP binds at the intradimer α1β1 interface in tetrameric HbA. α-Hemoglobin stabilizing protein (AHSP), 1The abbreviations used are: AHSP, α-hemoglobin stabilizing protein; RDC, residual dipolar coupling; HSQC, heteronuclear single quantum coherence spectroscopy; NOE, nuclear Overhauser effect; NOESY, nuclear Overhauser enhancement spectroscopy; K-MOPS, 3-(N-morpholino)propanesulfonic acid; ppm, parts/million; 1DNH, residual dipolar coupling constant between the amidic 1H and 15N atoms; 1JNH, scalar coupling constant between the amidic 1H and 15N atoms; TOCSY, total correlation spectroscopy; COSY, correlated spectroscopy. 1The abbreviations used are: AHSP, α-hemoglobin stabilizing protein; RDC, residual dipolar coupling; HSQC, heteronuclear single quantum coherence spectroscopy; NOE, nuclear Overhauser effect; NOESY, nuclear Overhauser enhancement spectroscopy; K-MOPS, 3-(N-morpholino)propanesulfonic acid; ppm, parts/million; 1DNH, residual dipolar coupling constant between the amidic 1H and 15N atoms; 1JNH, scalar coupling constant between the amidic 1H and 15N atoms; TOCSY, total correlation spectroscopy; COSY, correlated spectroscopy. previously named EDRF (erythroid differentiation-related factor), was originally identified as a protein that showed a decrease in expression in the hematopoietic tissues of rodents and cattle infected with transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (1Miele G. Manson J. Clinton M. Nat. Med. 2001; 7: 361-364Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar). EDRF was renamed AHSP after it was found that it binds specifically to α-hemoglobin in vitro (2Kihm A.J. Kong Y. Hong W. Russell J.E. Rouda S. Adachi K. Simon M.C. Blobel G.A. Weiss M.J. Nature. 2002; 417: 758-763Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar). AHSP knock-out mice show erythrocyte abnormalities similar to those observed in β-thalassemia (2Kihm A.J. Kong Y. Hong W. Russell J.E. Rouda S. Adachi K. Simon M.C. Blobel G.A. Weiss M.J. Nature. 2002; 417: 758-763Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar), and loss of AHSP aggravates the β-thalassemia phenotype in mice (38Kong Y. Katein A.M. Louden C.S. Weiss M.J. Blood. 2003; 102 (abstr.): 149Google Scholar). β-Thalassemia is characterized by a reduction in the synthesis of β-globin chains. Consequently, the α-chains are in excess, and some of them precipitate, leading to defective red blood cells that determine the pathophysiology of β-thalassemia syndromes. The in vivo and in vitro data therefore both suggest that AHSP acts as a molecular chaperone for free α-hemoglobin (2Kihm A.J. Kong Y. Hong W. Russell J.E. Rouda S. Adachi K. Simon M.C. Blobel G.A. Weiss M.J. Nature. 2002; 417: 758-763Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar, 3Luzzatto L. Notaro R. Nature. 2002; 417: 703-705Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). Both AHSP and α-hemoglobin are monomeric in solution and bind each other with an association constant of 1 × 107m-1 forming a complex with a 1:1 stoichiometry (4Gell D. Kong Y. Eaton S.A. Weiss M.J. Mackay J.P. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 40602-40609Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). The aim of the present study was to structurally characterize the AHSP-α-hemoglobin interaction to understand the molecular basis of the AHSP function and its role as a hemoglobin chaperone. We have demonstrated by NMR that the AHSP native state is conformationally heterogeneous in solution and have identified the dynamic source of this behavior as a cis/trans isomerization of residue Pro-30. The slow time scale of this phenomenon allowed us to determine the high resolution three-dimensional structure of the two conformations of the wild-type AHSP under conditions where both conformations are equally populated. We were able to quench the cis/trans equilibrium by rational site-directed mutagenesis (AHSP P30A), and the three-dimensional structure of the mutant was more similar to the trans conformation of the wild type. We have also shown, using chemical shift mapping, that AHSP binds to α-hemoglobin via an interface mainly located in the region between the first and the second helices. The major differences between the structures of the two forms of AHSP are located at the binding interface of the protein, suggesting that each conformation may have different ligand specificity. DNA Cloning—The DNA sequence for the full-length human AHSP was cloned from a human fetal liver cDNA library (Clontech) using the appropriate 5′- and 3′-end primers, which contained BamHI and EcoRI restriction sites, respectively. The resulting PCR product was ligated into a modified pRSETA vector (Invitrogen) containing a soluble hexahistidine-tagged GroEL fusion protein. AHSP mutants (P30A, M45K, and N75I) were constructed using the QuikChange site-directed mutagenesis kit (Stratagene). Protein Expression and Purification—The plasmid was transformed into C41 host cells (5Miroux B. Walker J.E. J. Mol. Biol. 1996; 260: 289-298Crossref PubMed Scopus (1567) Google Scholar) and grown in 2× TY medium or a modified K-MOPS minimal medium (6Neidhardt F.C. Bloch P.L. Smith D.F. J. Bacteriol. 1974; 119: 736-747Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) with 20 mm15NH4Cl and 0.4% [13C]glucose containing 50 μg/ml ampicillin. For deuterium-labeled proteins, medium containing 80% D2O was used. The cells were grown at 37 °C, induced with 1 mm isopropyl-1-thio-β-d-galactopyranoside when an A600 value of 0.8 was reached, and harvested after 4 h. Proteins were purified by affinity chromatography using nickel-nitrilotriacetic acid superflow resin (Qiagen). The bound protein was eluted from the resin with a buffer containing 250 mm imidazole, incubated with thrombin (10 units/ml) for 4 h at 37 °C, and dialyzed overnight to remove the imidazole. The solution was passed again through the nickel column, and untagged protein was collected in the flow-through. The resulting AHSP was concentrated before being applied to a Superdex 75 gel-filtration column (Amersham Biosciences). Fractions containing pure AHSP, as judged by SDS-PAGE and mass spectrometry, were pooled, concentrated, and dialyzed into the NMR buffer. Purification of α-Hemoglobin from Human Blood—CO gas was bubbled through packed red blood cells to form CO-Hb. The packed red blood cells were lysed with two volumes of cold distilled water. The method described by Antonini and Brunori (7Antonini E. Brunori M. Neuberger A. Tatum E.L. Frontiers of Biology. 21. North-Holland, Amsterdam1971: 1-30Google Scholar) was used to produce hemoglobin tetramers. p-Hydroxymercuribenzoate was used to isolate α-hemoglobin. Isolated α-hemoglobin was purified and equilibrated with 150 mm NaCl and 20 mm phosphate buffer at pH 7.0 using a Superdex 75 column from Amersham Biosciences. NMR Sample Preparation—Protein samples for NMR spectroscopy were typically 0.5–1.0 mm in 90% H2O, 10% 2H2O, 5% sodium azide containing 50 mm NaCl and 50 mm potassium phosphate buffer (pH 6.0) or 150 mm NaCl and 20 mm potassium phosphate buffer (pH 7.0) for the binding experiments and their corresponding controls. NMR Spectroscopy—All of the NMR spectra were recorded at 298 K on Bruker DRX-500, Avance-600, and Avance-800 spectrometers. Backbone assignments were obtained from two-dimensional 1H-15N HSQC and three-dimensional HNCO, HN(CA)CO, HNCACB, and CBCA- (CO)NH experiments (8Sattler M. Schleucher J. Griesinger C. Prog. NMR Spectrosc. 1999; 34: 93-158Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (1377) Google Scholar). Two-dimensional TOCSY, double quantum filtered-COSY, and 1H-13C HSQC and three-dimensional HCCH-COSY and 15N-edited total correlation spectroscopy experiments were acquired to complete the side chain assignments. Distance constraints were obtained from two-dimensional NOESY experiments analyzed in combination with 15N- and 13C-edited NOESY spectra recorded at a mixing time of 100 ms. Leu and Val stereospecific methyl assignments were obtained from 1H-13C HSQC spectra of 10% 13C-labeled samples. Three-dimensional HNHB and two-dimensional double quantum filtered-COSY spectra were used for the stereospecific assignment of CβH proton resonances. Spectra were referenced relative to external sodium 2,2-dimethyl-2-silapentane-5-sulfonate for proton and carbon signals or liquid ammonium for that of nitrogen. All of the NMR spectra were processed with NMRPipe (9Delaglio F. Grzesiek S. Vuister G.W. Zhu G. Pfeifer J. Bax A. J. Biomol. NMR. 1995; 6: 277-293Crossref PubMed Scopus (11450) Google Scholar) and analyzed with ANSIG (version 3.3) (10Helgstrand M. Kraulis P. Allard P. Hard T. J. Biomol. NMR. 2000; 18: 329-336Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar). 1DNH residual dipolar couplings (RDCs) were measured at 298 K on Pf1 phage-containing samples (11Hansen M.R. Mueller L. Pardi A. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1998; 5: 1065-1074Crossref PubMed Scopus (687) Google Scholar) of the wild-type AHSP (∼0.8 mm, 15N-labeled) and the AHSP mutant P30A (∼0.5 mm, 15N/2H-double labeled) in 50 mm NaCl and 50 mm potassium phosphate buffer (pH 6.0). Pf1 phage (ASLA Biotech, Ltd., Riga, Latvia) was added at a concentration of 8 mg/ml and 12 mg/ml for the wild type and the mutant, respectively. 1DNH RDCs were obtained from the peak displacement in the f2 dimension of two separate two-dimensional 1H-15N TROSY spectra (12Lerche M.H. Meissner A. Poulsen F.M. Sorensen O.W. J. Magn. Reson. 1999; 140: 259-263Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). Values of 1JNH obtained from isotropic phase control experiments lacking the Pf1 were subtracted from the peak splittings observed in the aligned phase spectra. All splittings were determined from one-dimensional traces as the displacement that produces the maximum integral of the overlap region between corresponding traces from the two spectra. Complex samples were prepared by adding a 1.5-fold excess of unlabeled α-hemoglobin solution to 15N,13C-labeled AHSP (both in 150 mm NaCl and 20 mm potassium phosphate buffer, pH 7.0). Complex formation was monitored at 298 K by two-dimensional 1H-15N HSQC spectra. Assignments for bound AHSP were obtained from three-dimensional HNCA, HN(CO)CA, and CBCA(CO)NH experiments (8Sattler M. Schleucher J. Griesinger C. Prog. NMR Spectrosc. 1999; 34: 93-158Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (1377) Google Scholar). Structure Calculation—The inter-proton distance constraints were classified into four categories corresponding to 1.8–2.8, 1.8–3.5, 1.8–4.75, and 1.8–6.0 Å, respectively. To maintain a hydrogen bond, constraints of 1.8–2.1 and 2.7–3.1 Å were imposed on the distances between the hydrogen and the donor nitrogen, respectively, and the acceptor oxygen. Torsion angle constraints were obtained from the stereospecific assignment of residue side chains and incorporated in the structure calculation along with the backbone ϕ and Ψ angle constraints determined with the program TALOS (13Cornilescu G. Delaglio F. Bax A. J. Biomol. NMR. 1999; 13: 289-302Crossref PubMed Scopus (2732) Google Scholar). To incorporate the dipolar couplings into the structure calculation, we obtained initial values of the axial (Da) and rhombic (Dr) components of the molecular alignment tensor using the program PALES (14Zweckstetter M. Bax A. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2000; 122: 3791-3792Crossref Scopus (593) Google Scholar). We could not estimate those values from the histogram distribution of dipolar couplings (15Clore G.M. Gronenborn A.M. Bax A. J. Magn. Reson. 1998; 133: 216-221Crossref PubMed Scopus (333) Google Scholar), because as the AHSP structure is highly anisotropic, we cannot assume a uniform isotropic distribution of the N-H vectors. Final values of Da (12.8 Hz) and Dr (3.2 Hz) were obtained for both the wild-type and the P30A mutant through a grid search by minimizing the total energy of the calculated structures. The structures were calculated using a standard torsion angle dynamics-simulated annealing protocol with the program CNS (16Brunger A.T. Adams P.D. Clore G.M. DeLano W.L. Gros P. Grosse-Kunstleve R.W. Jiang J.S. Kuszewski J. Nilges M. Pannu N.S. Read R.J. Rice L.M. Simonson T. Warren G.L. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1998; 54: 905-921Crossref PubMed Scopus (16948) Google Scholar). 20 structures were accepted where no distance violations were >0.3 Å, no angle violations were >5.0°, and no RDC violations were >2.5 Hz. Circular Dichroism Spectropolarimetry—Spectra were collected on an Aviv 215 spectropolarimeter using a 0.1-cm path length cell. Protein samples were prepared in 10 mm potassium phosphate buffer (pH 6.0). Spectra were collected at 298 K from 200–260 nm by taking points at 1-nm intervals with a bandwidth of 1 nm. A settling time of 1 s and an averaging time of 3 s were used. Spectra were typically the average of three scans. For the thermal denaturation experiments, the ellipticity at 222 nm was monitored from 4 to 98 °C, using a resolution of 0.2 °C, a bandwidth of 1 nm, and a temperature gradient of 1 °C min-1. Conformational Heterogeneity of AHSP—The line width and dispersion of the signals observed in the 1H-15N HSQC spectrum of AHSP are indicative of a folded protein of molecular weight 11,000. However, the number of correlation signals significantly exceeds that expected for a 102-residue protein (Fig. 1). Assignment of the spectra using triple resonance experiments acquired by using a double labeled (13C, 15N) sample revealed that almost two-thirds of the amide signals (residues 19–53 and 73–94) are duplicated. A monomer/dimer equilibrium can be ruled out as a source of the extra signals on the basis of gel filtration chromatography and 1H amide T2 relaxation measurements (data not shown), both of which indicate that AHSP is monomeric in solution at the concentrations used for protein structural determination by NMR (∼1 mm). This conclusion is in agreement with a previous biophysical characterization of AHSP (4Gell D. Kong Y. Eaton S.A. Weiss M.J. Mackay J.P. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 40602-40609Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). Hence, an intramolecular conformational exchange is the only plausible mechanism responsible for the extra signals in the 1H-15N HSQC spectrum (also observed in the 1H and the 1H-13C HSQC spectra). The volume integration of isolated cross-peaks corresponding to the two conformations indicates that the populations of both forms are approximately equal at room temperature. Based on 1H and 15N chemical shift differences, the estimated lower limit of the lifetime of the two species is 0.1 s. Evidence for Pro-30 cis/trans Isomerization—Proline cis/trans isomerization is one of the dynamic processes slow enough to account for the unusual conformational behavior of AHSP (17Wuthrich K. NMR of Protein and Nucleic Acids. John Wiley & Sons, Inc., New York1986: 263Google Scholar). In agreement with this hypothesis, we observed that in the two-dimensional NOESY spectrum, NOEs characteristic of both the cis and the trans conformations of the Asp-29–Pro-30 bond are present (supplementary Fig. 1). The chemical shift difference between the 13Cβ and the 13Cγ nuclei for the two conformations of residue Pro-30 of AHSP are 4.59 and 9.14 ppm. These values are in good agreement with the average values (4.51 and 9.64 ppm, respectively for the trans and the cis conformation of the Xaa–Pro bond) estimated for the two isomers from statistical analysis of 13C chemical shifts of proline residues in proteins (18Schubert M. Labudde D. Oschkinat H. Schmieder P. J. Biomol. NMR. 2002; 24: 149-154Crossref PubMed Scopus (275) Google Scholar). The other two proline residues within the folded region of AHSP (Pro-60 and Pro-80) where found to contain trans peptide bonds according to both the NOE pattern and the 13Cβ and 13Cγ chemical shift values criteria. As an independent test of the validity of the Pro-30 cis/trans equilibrium hypothesis, we decided to mutate this residue to an alanine. The AHSP mutant P30A was expressed and purified, and its structure was analyzed by NMR. An overlay of the 1H-15N HSQC spectra of the wild-type AHSP and the AHSP mutant P30A is shown in Fig. 2. The single point mutation has a dramatic effect on the NMR spectrum. The number of peaks is significantly reduced, indicating that the mutant adopts a unique conformation in contrast with the two conformations adopted by the wild-type AHSP. Comparison between the Structures of the cis and trans Forms of the Wild-type AHSP—The presence of the conformational equilibrium significantly increased the difficulty of both the assignment of the AHSP spectra and the structure determination. We were, however, able to assign specifically to each conformation a substantial number of medium and long range NOEs similar to those typically used in structure calculations of helical proteins of this size (Table I). 1DNH RDCs were also measured for 69 NH bonds of the two AHSP forms (Table I). These experimental restraints together with dihedral angle constraints (13Cornilescu G. Delaglio F. Bax A. J. Biomol. NMR. 1999; 13: 289-302Crossref PubMed Scopus (2732) Google Scholar) were used for the structure calculation of the cis and the trans conformations of AHSP. Both backbone and side chains are reasonably well defined for both conformations (Fig. 3). In both conformations of AHSP, helix 3 is significantly kinked because of the presence of Pro-80 in the middle of it. The three α-helices are arranged with a very rare right-handed twist.
